channel.title: Downloading JAR
channel.description: Hello all you elitists, Just a quick, but probably simple question about downloading a JAR. Runescape currently doesn't include EVERY file in their JARs. In fact, for a while now, their JARs haven't included every directory. it includes the files IN the directory, but not the directory itself. or perhaps it is just named that way(i.e. jagex3/jagmisc/jagmisc.class). Who knows how their British minds function. Anyways my question is this. How would one go about extracting these directories in an efficient manner? Writing this I realize that there are many points that you could flame me on, but please, enough of the nonsense.

item.title: Downloading JAR
item.dc:creator: @skepskep skepskep
item.description:
@skepskep wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:29, topic:333223”]1: http://www.spellingcity.com/
2: being retarded and cool are mutually exclusive (Google it)

@zyle it says there are no available bytes from the client … perhaps because the client hasn’t sent anything? (Generally speaking you handle reading/writing in a separate thread or use something like NIO)
see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_I/O
Note that you might also be fucking up the login protocol[/quote]

So what you’re saying is, I’m cool?

How’s he suppose to fuck up the login protocol when nothing has been sent, unless the server has to send a response to the connection being received…

Read full topic

item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“skepskep, post:23, topic:333223”]Go away, noob if that was directed toward my overly optimistic helpyness behavior

Cuz I am cool liek dat[/quote]

1: http://www.spellingcity.com/
2: being retarded and cool are mutually exclusive (Google it)

@zyle it says there are no available bytes from the client … perhaps because the client hasn’t sent anything? (Generally speaking you handle reading/writing in a separate thread or use something like NIO)
see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_I/O
Note that you might also be fucking up the login protocol

OK, i got it under control, but now I have another question. Now this may seems like an rsps question, and it kind of is, but it also involves java mechanics.

Ok, so writing my server I’ve come across a problem. It says that there’s no available bytes from the client. What would cause this sort of behavior?

item.title: Downloading JAR
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

Why not just use a JarOutputStream? Idk why you’re making directories, at least if you used the JarOutputStream you don’t need to. When it looms like directories it’s specifying the package of the class and it’ll automatically fix that up in the JarOutputStream

Read full topic

item.title: Downloading JAR
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I fixed it in 5 lines. >.<

EDIT: New problem. It seems that the jarInput.available() equals 1…

[code]
public static void extractJar(String jarName) throws IOException {
File jarFile = new File(jarName);
JarFile jar = new JarFile(jarFile);
File jarDir = new File(jarName.substring(0, jarName.indexOf(".jar")));
jarDir.mkdirs();
Enumeration entries = jar.entries();
while(entries.hasMoreElements()) {
JarEntry entry = entries.nextElement();
if(entry.getName().contains("/")) {
int index = entry.getName().lastIndexOf("/");
String dir = entry.getName().substring(0, index);
File file = new File(jarDir + “/” + dir);
file.mkdirs();
}
File entryFile = new File(jarDir + “/” + entry.getName());
if(debug) {
System.out.println(entry.getName());
}
if(entry.isDirectory()) {
continue;
}
JarInputStream jarInput = new JarInputStream(new FileInputStream(jarFile));
FileOutputStream fileOutput = new FileOutputStream(entryFile);
int size = (int) entry.getSize();
byte[] buffer = new byte[size];
int bytesRead = 0;
System.out.println(jarInput.available());
while((bytesRead = jarInput.read(buffer)) != -1) {
System.out.println(bytesRead);
fileOutput.write(buffer, 0, bytesRead);
}

		fileOutput.close();
		jarInput.closeEntry();
	}
}[/code]

What exactly am I doing wrong(Aside from the hideous code…)

Read full topic

item.title: Downloading JAR
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

JarFile

[code=Java]
JarFile jarFile = null;

    try {
       jarFile = new JarFile("runescape.jar");

        Enumeration<JarEntry> entries = jarFile.entries();

        JarEntry entry = null;
        while(entries.hasMoreElements()) {
            entry = entries.nextElement();
            
            // Handle the entry blah blah blah
        }
    } catch(IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    } finally {
        if(jarFile != null) {
            try {
                jarFile.close();
            } catch(IOException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }
        }
    }[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Downloading JAR
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“skepskep, post:13, topic:333223”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=429636.msg3154518#msg3154518 date=1268888251]

Sure, why not, it’s possible.

Packaging is just there for organization.

The program won’t function any differently if you remove, but it’s more organized and easy (to humans) if it’s packaged.

It’s the perfect crime!

And notice in any client the only sub directory in package is signlink or sign or whatever. (Atleast in 317 I stay away from that 500 shit :()

Go back to mscp. (And yes, I know a vast majority of my posts are from moparscape, so don’t try to use that argument against me, at least I’m TRYING to actually LEARN how to program efficiently and effectively, instead of “learn” how to “code” a “server”)
[/quote]

Except what I said is correct??

Why so abrasive? I’m just tryin’ to help you :\

EDIT: http://www.zelix.com/klassmaster/docs/obfuscateOptions.html

Skip to the collapse packages header[/quote]

My apologies. I knew not of this obfuscation option. Back to the subject, what would remedy this collapsed package option?

Read full topic
